results.title: The Elements of composition
results.creator_credit: Nina Collier, Lee R. Bobker and Dynamic Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Music for Young People”.
Defines and explains melody, harmony, rhythm and counterpoint to a young audience. Each element is illustrated by the New York Woodwind Quintet. The film emphasises that melody is full of character, the addition of harmony makes music complete, rhythm is of many kinds and can be felt and listening to counterpoint is like following a conversation. Summarises and contrasts the elements of composition through the playing of a harmonic, rhythmic and contrapuntal treatment of the melody. Script by Lydia Perera

results.title: The Elementary school = Obecna skola
results.creator_credit: Jaromir Lukas, Filmove Studio Barrandov and Jan Sverak
results.brief_description: A new teacher begins work at an elementary school in a small Czechoslovakian town closely following the second World War. This situation provides an historical backdrop for the exploration of a dark period in Czechoslovakian history. Sverak’s debut feature, written by his father (Zdenek Sverak) was the last film to represent the united Czechoslovakia, in the Foreign Language Film category of the 1991 Oscars (it lost to Italy’s entry “Mediterraneo”). Cast includes Jan Triska and Libuse Safrankova. In Czech with English subtitles.

results.title: The Elementary mind
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Southern California Consortium and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode number 17 of Series “Time to grow”.
This program discusses the development of complex thinking (reasoning, mathematics) during middle childhood, the stage Piaget referred to as the concrete and logical operations period.

results.title: The Electronic telephone
results.brief_description: This short film is about telecommunications, silicon technology, and the E-phone and Bell’s role in its development. The E-phone is the world’s first fully electronic telephone. Chips utilized in it were designed by Bell Northern Research in Ottawa. Northern Telecom makes 256 phones an hour, on one production line alone. As Canada changes, the telephone changes with it and this film includes historical glimpses with a montage of shots from a telephone museum.
results.description: This short film is about telecommunications, silicon technology, and the E-phone and Bell’s role in its development. The E-phone is the world’s first fully electronic telephone. results.title: The Electronic Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Electronic Office”.
A computer education program that consists of six parts, each 25 minutes long. The parts are: 1.”Office on the move”, 2.”The stand-alone micro”, 3. “Wiring up the organisation”, 4. “Changing with the times”, 5. “Wiring up the world”, 6.”Easy to use”.

results.title: The Electron's tale
results.creator_credit: Beryl Stevens, W.M. Larkins Studio, Film Producers Guild, Peter Green and Bob Godfrey
results.brief_description: Made to mark Mullard’s 50th anniversary. In a light-hearted vein, this film describes the development of electronics from the electron’s point of view. Live action scenes supplement the cartoon sequences unobtrusively to bring home the importance of the role played by electrons in our lives.

results.title: The Electromagnetic spectrum
results.creator_credit: Jack Smith and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Physics in action”.
Provides demonstrations of ultra-violet and infra-red radiation, radio waves and microwaves and shows the application of reflection of light in medical technology particularly X-ray machines, broadcasting and microwave ovens. Suitable for upper secondary level.
